message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings are consistent with Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is inflammation and infection causing injury to the intestinal lining in premature or low-birth-weight infants. Meckel diverticulum and Hirschsprung disease are less likely to present with the described symptoms. Cow milk protein allergy may present with vomiting and diarrhea but it is less likely to cause abdominal rigidity, distention, and absent bowel sounds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Necrotizing enterocolitis, which is most common in premature infants and those with low birth weight, like this patient. The fact that she has fed less, has decreased urine output, and has positive occult blood in the stool, along with the abdominal rigidity, distention, absent bowel sounds, and gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity seen on the x-ray all support this diagnosis. Meckel diverticulum usually presents with painless rectal bleeding. Cow milk protein allergy presents with gastroesophageal reflux, colic, and diarrhea. Hirschsprung disease presents with constipation and failure to pass meconium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs of abdominal rigidity, distention, absent bowel sounds, and positive stool occult blood suggest necrotizing enterocolitis, which is a common and serious gastrointestinal condition in premature infants. Meckel diverticulum usually causes painless rectal bleeding. Cow milk protein allergy and Hirschsprung disease do not typically present with gas in the intestinal wall and the peritoneal cavity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased urine output, and abdominal rigidity and distention, along with the positive stool test and gas in the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity on x-ray, suggest the most likely diagnosis is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Meckel diverticulum and Hirschsprung disease are possible causes of intestinal obstruction, but they do not typically present with the same symptoms as NEC. Cow milk protein allergy may cause gastrointestinal symptoms, but it is unlikely to cause the abdominal rigidity and distention seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of prematurity, is currently presenting with diarrhea, and has abdominal distention and rigidity, which are all suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis. The positive test for occult blood in the stool and gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity on an abdominal x-ray further support this diagnosis. Meckel diverticulum and Hirschsprung disease are possibilities but do not present with all of these symptoms. Cow milk protein allergy typically presents with skin symptoms and gastrointestinal symptoms such as blood in the stool but does not cause the abdominal rigidity and distention seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and diagnostic tests suggest necrotizing enterocolitis, which is a common gastrointestinal emergency in neonates. Meckel diverticulum and Hirschsprung disease usually present with different symptoms. Cow milk protein allergy may cause gastrointestinal symptoms but would not explain the positive stool test for occult blood or the gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity seen on x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea with decreased urine output and abdominal symptoms suggests a gastrointestinal issue. The positive occult blood test, gas in the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity, and the patient being premature, suggests necrotizing enterocolitis. Meckel diverticulum would present with painless rectal bleeding, cow milk protein allergy would not cause these abdominal symptoms, and Hirschsprung disease would present with constipation and failure to pass meconium in the neonatal period.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant has symptoms consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), including fever, vomiting, and diarrhea, as well as abdominal rigidity, distention, and absent bowel sounds. The positive test for occult blood and the x-ray findings of gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity also support the diagnosis of NEC. Meckel diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that can cause intestinal obstruction, but it usually presents with lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Cow milk protein allergy can cause gastrointestinal symptoms, but it is not typically associated with abdominal rigidity and absent bowel sounds. Hirschsprung disease is a congenital disorder characterized by a absence of ganglion cells in the colon, but it usually presents with constipation rather than diarrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea with decreased urine output and positive stool for occult blood suggest a gastrointestinal infection or inflammation. The x-ray findings of gas within the intestinal wall and peritoneal cavity indicate necrotizing enterocolitis, a severe gastrointestinal emergency common in premature infants. Meckel diverticulum presents with painless rectal bleeding, while cow milk protein allergy and Hirschsprung disease are unlikely to cause the acute and severe symptoms described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, positive stool test for occult blood, and x-ray findings all point towards the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Meckel diverticulum may cause gastrointestinal bleeding but not NEC symptoms. Cow milk protein allergy may cause feeding intolerance but not the distension and rigidity seen in NEC. Hirschsprung disease may cause constipation and bowel obstruction but would not present with the acute onset of symptoms seen in this case.
